motifs.title: Taotie Motif
motifs.content:
The taotie motif is a frontal zoomorphic mask with large eyes, horns, and fangs. It often appears symmetrical and integrated with geometric patterns.

This motif symbolizes spiritual power and protection during rituals.

motifs.title: Kuilong Motif
motifs.content:
The Kuilong (Dragon) motif depicts a long-bodied creature shown in profile, often with curved tails and phoenix-like crests.

It represents divine guardianship and cosmic harmony.

motifs.title: Inscriptions
motifs.content: Long inscriptions recording historical events or familial lineage became central decorative features on bronzeware.

motifs.title: Panchi Motif
motifs.content: The panchi motif features curly dragons with slender bodies, often arranged in dense, continuous, and symmetrical patterns. They are designed to connect seamlessly in all four directions (up, down, left, right).

motifs.title: Mountain
motifs.content: Mountain motifs became a defining feature of Han dynasty incense burners, especially the boshanlu, where the lids were cast in the form of miniature peaks.

motifs.title: Cloud
motifs.content: Auspicious cloud motifs are among the most enduring and meaningful symbols in Chinese culture. In the Han dynasty, cloud motifs were formalized into elegant, swirling scrolls.
